Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Models and Algorithms for Comparative Analysis of Biological Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent advent of high-throughput technologies for measuring molecular interactions has yielded large collections of biological networks, which enable systematic studies of complex biological organisms. Since biological pathways with critical functions are often conserved across different organisms, comparative analysis of these networks can provide an excellent way of investigating the organization of biological networks, as well as tracking down novel pathways and studying their functions.
Intellectual Merit: This project aims to develop a solid mathematical framework for comparative network analysis and devise innovative techniques for comparing genome-scale biological networks. The main research objectives include: (1) develop a multi-state semi-Markov random walk (SMRW) model for probabilistic comparison of large-scale networks; (2) develop efficient algorithms for querying and aligning biological networks; (3) apply the developed algorithms to identify novel biological pathways and investigate their functions and their detailed mechanisms.
Broader Impact: The research activities in this project are closely integrated with a comprehensive educational plan, whose overall goal lies in enhancing students? learning experience through the integration of research and education. This goal is translated into a three-part educational plan: (1) develop a concept inventory (CI) for genomic signal processing and computational biology (called the CIGSP); (2) shift a graduate-level course on ?Probabilistic Graphical Models? to a problem-based format; (3) design a new undergraduate course on Probabilistic Models for Network Biology based on proven and emerging pedagogical approaches. The new concept inventory CIGSP will provide a valuable diagnosis/assessment tool for enhancing education in genomic signal processing and computational biology, and it will be used in the PI?s courses, to design measurable educational objectives and evaluate the learning outcomes.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this research project is to develop a solid probabilistic framework for comparative analysis of biological networks and develop innovative techniques for network querying and network alignment.

 

Intellectual Merit

Several novel comparative network analysis frameworks have been developed during this project, which include:
(1) semi-Markov random walk (SMRW) model
(2) context-sensitive random walk (CSRW) model
(3) CUFID framework based on the concept of steady-state network flow estimation.

These developed models can provide the mathematical and computational foundations for probabilistically comparing and analyzing large-scale biological networks. These models have been used to develop novel network alignment and network querying algorithms that are computationally efficient, robust, accurate, and highly scalable, hence suitable for network analysis tasks that involve a large number of genome-scale biological networks.

 

Broader Impacts

This project has provided opportunites for several graduate and undergraduate students to be involved in interdisciplinary research activities on emerging research problems in computational biology and data science. Four Ph.D theses on relevant topics have resulted from this project, and two undergraduate students were actively involved in the project as REU participants. Furthermore, the project provided training opportunites for female students and minority students. The research findings of the project have been widely disseminated through journal publications, conference presentations, invited seminars, tutorials, keynotes at various international and domestic venues.

 

Summary of Outcomes

During this project, three novel probabilistic models for comparative network analysis have been developed: semi-Markov random walk (SMRW) model, context-sensitive random walk (CSRW) model, and the CUFID model based on the concept of network flow. Based on the SMRW model, a scalable network alignment algorithm called SMETANA and a robust network querying algorithm called RESQUE were developed. The CSRW model was used to develop an enhanced network alignmnent algorithm called SMETANA-CSRW and a network querying algorithm called SEQUOIA that enhances the biological significance of the querying results. The CUFID model was used to develop a novel network alignment algorithm called CUFID-align and a novel network querying algorithm called CUFID-query, both of which were shown to improve the network analysis results.

In this project, a novel method was developed for synthesizing families of related protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks and it was used to develop the first comprehensive benchmark - called NAPAbench (Network Alignment Performance Assessment benchmark) - for performance evaluation of multiple network alignment algorithms. The created benchmark has been already widely utilized and/or cited in a large number of published work, facilitating future advances in comparative network analysis and computational network biology.

Research findings and reserach components of this reserach project have been incoporated in several undergraduate/graduate courses taught by the PI, with the goal of enhancing the students' learning experience through the integration of emerging research problems and results into engineering education.

The research findings obtained throughout this project have been widely disseminated through journal publications, conference presentations, and giving invited seminars, tutorials, keynote speeches at various international and domestic venues. Furthermore, an edited book is currently being prepared by the PI, where the book will contain the latest advances in the emerging field of computational network biology, which will also include the results obtained from this project. Furthermore, the PI has been organizing an annual international workshop on computational network biology since 2014, called CNB-MAC (International Workshop on Computational Network Biology: Modeling, Analysis, and Control). The workshop has been serving as an international scientific forum for presenting the latest advances in computational network biology.


Last Modified: 05/12/2018
Modified by: Byung-Jun Yoon
